title: Lecture 2 — Files and Filesystems (Part 1)

questions.prompt: Which statement best describes a file?

options.text: A named collection of bytes; interpretation depends on format.

questions.explanation: Every file is bytes; type/meaning follows conventions like headers and encodings.

sources.path: Year1/Semester1/Introduction to Digital Skills and Programming/Lectures/Lecture_2_DSIP
sources.heading: File types and how data is stored

questions.prompt: What does execute permission mean on a directory?

options.text: You can run the directory as a program.

questions.explanation: Execute on a directory controls the ability to traverse into it.

sources.path: Year1/Semester1/Introduction to Digital Skills and Programming/Lectures/Lecture_2_DSIP
sources.heading: Directory trees

questions.prompt: Where is a file’s real type recorded?

options.text: In the file’s header / internal structure.

questions.explanation: Extensions are UI hints; the internal header/structure encodes real type.

sources.path: Year1/Semester1/Introduction to Digital Skills and Programming/Lectures/Lecture_2_DSIP
sources.heading: Extensions vs “real” type

questions.prompt: Which items reside in file system metadata (not in the file header)?
questions.explanation: FS metadata: name, path, perms, location; file header: real type signature/magic + format.

sources.path: Year1/Semester1/Introduction to Digital Skills and Programming/Lectures/Lecture_2_DSIP
sources.heading: File structure components

questions.prompt: Which encoding stores Unicode using 1–4 bytes and is ASCII-compatible?
questions.explanation: UTF-8 is variable-length and backward-compatible with ASCII.

sources.path: Year1/Semester1/Introduction to Digital Skills and Programming/Lectures/Lecture_2_DSIP
sources.heading: Text encodings

questions.prompt: Which UTF-8 pattern matches a 3-byte character?
questions.explanation: 3-byte form uses 1110xxxx followed by two 10xxxxxx continuation bytes.

sources.path: Year1/Semester1/Introduction to Digital Skills and Programming/Lectures/Lecture_2_DSIP
sources.heading: UTF-8 byte patterns

questions.prompt: Which statement about compression is true per the lecture?
questions.explanation: Lossless preserves information; lossy trades fidelity for ratio.

sources.path: Year1/Semester1/Introduction to Digital Skills and Programming/Lectures/Lecture_2_DSIP
sources.heading: Compression

questions.prompt: Which best describes the dictionary approach to lossless compression?

options.text: Store only unique bytes and discard the rest.
Replace repeated patterns with shorter references to a dictionary.
Convert binary to text for smaller size.

questions.explanation: Lecture example maps repeated phrases to indices, reducing total bytes.

sources.path: Year1/Semester1/Introduction to Digital Skills and Programming/Lectures/Lecture_2_DSIP
sources.heading: Lossless idea (dictionary approach)

questions.prompt: Which item is NOT a file category listed in the notes?
questions.explanation: Text, executables, and binary formats are covered; 'quantum state files' are not.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is true about ASCII and UTF-8 compatibility?

options.text: ASCII characters are not valid UTF-8.
All ASCII bytes map directly to single-byte UTF-8 codes starting with 0.
ASCII requires two bytes in UTF-8.
UTF-8 cannot represent ASCII control codes.

questions.explanation: The notes state ASCII is backward-compatible: same single-byte values in UTF-8.

sources.path: Year1/Semester1/Introduction to Digital Skills and Programming/Lectures/Lecture_2_DSIP

questions.prompt: Which is a property of HDD/SSD described in the notes?

options.text: They are non-volatile; data persists without power.

questions.explanation: Lecture states HDD/SSD are non-volatile and may be partitioned.

sources.heading: Storage and disks

questions.prompt: Select all correct statements about directory trees from the lecture.

options.text: The root is a drive (e.g., C: or /).
Leaves can be files or links/shortcuts.
Permissions apply to both folders and files.

questions.explanation: Inner nodes are directories, leaves include files/links, and permissions exist for both.
